fields.description:
On a scale set up with super CPU over commit (128 cores vs 8 real one) NC could fails with
{code}
2016-02-26 16:05:31 ERROR 000009189 lock_hypervisor_conn     | timed out on libvirt refreshing thread
2016-02-26 16:05:31 DEBUG 000010734 nc_signal_handler        | signal handler caught 10
{code}
NC that started to report messages like this one are not responding to CC's pulls. CC logs are have this
{code}
2016-02-26 16:09:29 ERROR 000007067 timeread                 | select() timed out for read: timeout=20
2016-02-26 16:09:29 ERROR 000007067 ncClientCall             | BUG: child process 7068 handling 'ncDescribeResource' was terminated with 1 (core=0)
2016-02-26 16:09:29 ERROR 000007067 refresh_resources        | bad return from ncDescribeResource(10.112.10.57) (1)
2016-02-26 16:09:29 ERROR 000007067 refresh_resources        | error message from ncDescribeResource: UNSET
{code}
The 'virsh list' is still working even that we can't connect to libvirt.


Side note. For some reason nodes only from one cluster were affected
{code}
[root@scale-01-01-01 test]# euserv-describe-node-controllers | grep NODE

fields.summary: timed out on libvirt refreshing thread

comments.body: I see the same issue agagin across all nodes in the scale system. Each node serves 30+ instances at the moment.
NC with significant number of VMs (30+) going into that state in idle mode in about 8 hours. Will create a system to check how NC behaves with instance churn.
[~dcalzago], overloaded NC under constant churn has the same issue after about 15 hours :(
The connection problem goes away after libvirtd restart.
I've lowered load on my test NC to 30 VMs per 4 cores to check if it makes a difference.

With only 30+/-1 constantly running VMs I don't see any new timed out message in logs after 24 hours. I am wondering if the issue somehow related to total number of open/close connections. I would leave system running to see if it would show any new 'timed out' messages with the current load.
Funny enough the system started to report timeout after 25+ hours of work.
Similar complain with the same simptoms https://forum.opennebula.org/t/hosts-entering-the-error-state/2273

This page https://forum.opennebula.org/t/polkitd-traps-general-protection-ip-in-libmozjs-17-0-so/399/2?source_topic_id=1718 claims that "It's related to PolicyKit, which crashes after many authentication checks." and offers to turn off auth :(. The bug that is referenced https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=69501 states that the issue should be fixed in polkit-0.113. The box that I am using has polkit-0.112-6.el7_2.x86_64. [~gholms], I need your input on that. Could we host polkit-0.113?

[~vasya], here is another libvirt issue that we have just seen. I do not know if it is related or not.

NC.log snippet
{code}

With Polkit-0.113 on RHEL 7.2 with 60 instances running libvirt stops responding after about 14 hours. It looks like there is a bigger delay before issue but the problem still present. On the CentOS 6.7 with Polkit-0.96 system runs without timeouts.
[~tony], I don't know if your issue is related or not.

For the record. How to install polkit-0.113
{code}
rpm -U ftp://rpmfind.net/linux/centos/7.2.1511/os/x86_64/Packages/glib2-devel-2.42.2-5.el7.x86_64.rpm
rpm -U ftp://195.220.108.108/linux/centos/7.2.1511/updates/x86_64/Packages/nspr-devel-4.11.0-1.el7_2.x86_64.rpm
rpm -U ftp://195.220.108.108/linux/centos/7.2.1511/os/x86_64/Packages/mozjs17-devel-17.0.0-12.el7.x86_64.rpm
yum -y install expat-devel intltool gtk-doc systemd-devel gobject-introspection-devel
./configure --enable-gtk-doc \
        --disable-static \
        --enable-introspection \
        --disable-examples \
        --enable-libsystemd-login=yes --with-mozjs=mozjs-17.0
make
make install
{code}

I've added libvirtd restart on errors and got:
{code}
2016-06-23 22:53:35 ERROR 000028204 timewait                 | waitpid() timed out: pid=28351
2016-06-23 22:53:35 ERROR 000028204 lock_hypervisor_conn     | timed out waiting for hypervisor checker pid=28351
2016-06-23 22:53:40 ERROR 000028204 timewait                 | waitpid() timed out: pid=29257
2016-06-23 22:53:40 ERROR 000028204 lock_hypervisor_conn     | timed out waiting for hypervisor checker pid=29257
2016-06-23 22:53:45 ERROR 000028204 timewait                 | waitpid() timed out: pid=29634
2016-06-23 22:53:45 ERROR 000028204 lock_hypervisor_conn     | timed out waiting for hypervisor checker pid=29634

2016-06-23 22:53:56 ERROR 000028204 lock_hypervisor_conn     | timed out waiting for hypervisor checker pid=29640
2016-06-23 22:53:56  WARN 000028204 refresh_instance_info    | Got 5 connection errors to libvirt. Restarting libvirtd service...

2016-06-23 22:54:27 ERROR 000028204 lock_hypervisor_conn     | timed out waiting for hypervisor checker pid=29790
2016-06-23 22:54:32 ERROR 000028204 timewait                 | waitpid() timed out: pid=29791

2016-06-23 22:54:42 ERROR 000028204 timewait                 | waitpid() timed out: pid=31088
2016-06-23 22:54:42 ERROR 000028204 lock_hypervisor_conn     | timed out waiting for hypervisor checker pid=31088
2016-06-23 22:54:47 ERROR 000028204 timewait                 | waitpid() timed out: pid=31089

2016-06-23 22:54:47  WARN 000028204 refresh_instance_info    | Got 5 connection errors to libvirt. Restarting libvirtd service...
{code}
Right now I don't have lock on restart and did not wait after restart. I will add wait and commit the change to unblock QA's long testing. Meanwhile I will open a new bug so [~jbreiding], could search for a better solution.

[~dmitrii], I've also lowered monitoring thread sleep time to 2 seconds so I would hit error sooner. I hit the issue in about 11 hours instead of projected 4-5 hours base on assumption that issue manifests itself after some number of connections made to libvirt and previous rate of open/close connections per hour.
Addressed in e1cc2d7de54607bffb4e138fa310dadffc59a94f
Sorry, seemed to have mis-clicked and assigned this to me. Do. Not. Want.

Fix Verified

With NCs on the scale setup severely overprovisioned (128 cores with 8 real) max instances of 4096 running for over 16 hours (~70 VMs per NC) no NCs went to not ready, CC kept tabs of NCs and none of the libvirt connection waiting in logs.
